where in the second line we have treated the infinite sum via zeta function regularization.

\footnote{${\text{Pol}(\Delta)}$ is sufficient to account for any zeta function regularization ambiguities in the cases we study; we expect this behavior to be generic.} 

$\zeta(s,x)$ is the Hurwitz zeta function, found by the analytic continuation of $\zeta(s,x)=\sum_{k=0}^\infty(x+k)^{-s}$, and $\zeta'(s,x) = \partial_s \zeta(s,x)$.

The only undetermined part of the partition function $Z({\Delta})$ at this point is the polynomial ${\text{Pol}(\Delta)}$. This polynomial encodes the behavior of $Z({\Delta})$ at large ${\Delta}$, which can be computed from a large mass heat kernel expansion, where ${\Delta}$ and $m$ are related by (\ref{eq:deltaandm}). The heat kernel expansion of $Z({\Delta})$ at large $m$ (and thus large $\Delta$) for a generic spacetime of dimension $d+1$ is given by \cite{Vassilevich:2003xt},

where we have abbreviated $L_{\pm 1}=L_\pm$.
The quadratic Casimir for this algebra is $L_0^2  - L_0 -L_{-}L_{+}$.  States with well-defined conformal dimension ${\Delta}$ are also eigenstates of the Casimir, with eigenvalue ${\Delta}({\Delta}-1)$. 

Since we want to find the specific values ${\Delta}_\star$ at which (\ref{eq:scalarpoles}) has a solution $\phi_\star$, we consider states with a well-defined ${\Delta}$.  Since these are Casimir eigenstates, we use ${\Delta}$ to label the representations we study. A particular state can be specified by its $L_0$ eigenvalue $\ell_0$ combined with ${\Delta}$. Note $L_\pm$ act as lowering/raising operators on the eigenvalue $\ell_0$. Additionally, since the quasinormal mode method will only work when the degeneracy of the states $\phi_\star$ is finite, we will insist that the representations have finite length.

If a representation labelled by ${\Delta}$ has finite length, then it must have a highest weight state satisfying

\subsection{Matching these scalar states to those from \cite{Keeler:2014hba}}
In the previous section, we did not impose boundary conditions on the functional form of the scalar states.  Instead, we simply insisted that the states in which we are interested should be in finite representations labelled by a fixed value of ${\Delta}$.  These restrictions resulted in the same number of states for each ${\Delta}$ as we found via boundary conditions in \cite{Keeler:2014hba}, shown here in Eq. (\ref{eq:explicitphistar}).

We now show that these two sets of states are related to each other via linear combination; consequently, the algebraic conditions do also impose the boundary conditions in Eq. (\ref{eq:bcandperiodic}).  The lowest case, when $h=0$, is actually quite trivial; both functions are just constants and thus equivalent up to overall normalization.

nexttext:
It is additionally useful to recall that $L_+\phi_h=0$, and $L_0\phi_h=h\phi_h$.  Using these facts, we can write explicit expressions for $L_-^k\phi_h$ as linear combinations of the $\phi_{h,l}$, and each linear combination is unique; however the general expressions are not particularly illuminating so we do not reproduce them here.

Instead, we now move on to discuss the boundary conditions.  Since the highest weight states and their descendants can all be written as linear combinations of the $\phi_{h,l}$ from \cite{Keeler:2014hba}, they inherit their boundary conditions, namely smoothness at $\eta=0$, periodicity in $\theta$, and the falloff condition Eq. (\ref{eq:bcandperiodic}). In fact, the highest weight condition $L_+\phi_h=0$ together with the finite representation condition $L_-^{-2h+1}\phi_h=0$ impose both smooth regular behavior at the center of Euclidean AdS and the boundary condition at infinity.

We can use this fact to write the falloff condition Eq. (\ref{eq:bcandperiodic}) in a coordinate invariant manner.  States can always be labelled by the eigenvalues of a complete set of commuting operators; in AdS$_2$, we can choose the Casimir with eigenvalue $\Delta(\Delta-1)$ and $L_0$ with eigenvalue $\ell_0$.  The boundary conditions can then be rewritten as these eigenvalues satisfying

nexttext:
In order to be killed by $p+1$ derivatives, the function of $t$ must to be a polynomial of degree $p$ or lower. If $p$ is even, $[1+(t/z)^2]^{\frac{p-1}{2}}$ is not polynomial and in fact is not killed by $(\partial_t)^{p+1}$. Hence $p$ must be an odd number, in which case $[1+(t/z)^2]^{\frac{p-1}{2}}$ and $(t/z) [1+(t/z)^2]^{\frac{p-1}{2}}$ are polynomial with degrees $p-1$ and $p$ respectively. 

We already knew from the commutation relations that $2h$ must be a nonpositive integer; we have now shown that the functional form of the spinor modes additionally requires that $2h$ is odd, or $h= -p - 1/2$ for for $p \in {\mathbb Z}_{\geq 0}$.

If we consider each chirality separately, then for a given $p$, we have $2(-h)+1=2(p+1)$ states:

so the modes we computed correspond to zeros in the spin half partition function, and there are no poles. Here $m$ is again a function of ${\Delta}$, given by $m=\Delta-{1 \over 2}$.

Following the logic we used for the scalar field, we use Weierstrass's factorization theorem to write

\subsection{Generalization to AdS$_{4}$}
Similarly to the scalar case (as discussed in \ref{sec:higherscalar}), the algebraic method of finding finite dimensional spinor representations of $SO(d+1,1)$ involves finding the zero-eigenvalues of the inner-product matrix at each level for a spinor highest weight representation. We have diagonalized the inner-product matrix for the case of AdS$_4$ to find these finite representations up to a few levels. 
The details are provided in Appendix~\ref{sec:higherspinor}.

In fact, we can use these results alone to recover the logarithmic portion of the spinor one loop effective action in the existing literature.
We first use Eq.~(\ref{eq:logZ}) with $-h=-{\Delta}_\star = p +\frac{1}{2}$, $p=0,1,2,\ldots$ and degeneracies $D(p)=\frac{2}{3} (p+1) (p+2) (p+3)$ to find

\begin{eqnarray}
\log{Z} &=& \textrm{Pol}({\Delta}) +\frac{2}{3} \sum_{p=0}^\infty (p+1) (p+2) (p+3)\log\bigg({\Delta}+p+\frac{1}{2}\bigg), \\
& =& \textrm{Pol}({\Delta}) 
-\frac{2}{3}\left[
\zeta'\left(-3,{\Delta}+{1 \over 2}\right)
+3\left(2-{\Delta}\right)\zeta'\left(-2,{\Delta}+{1 \over 2}\right)
\right.
\\ 
&&\left.
+\left(3{\Delta}^2-12 \Delta+11\right) \zeta'\left(-1,{\Delta}+{1 \over 2}\right)
- ({\Delta} -1)({\Delta} -2)({\Delta} -3) 
\zeta'\left(0,{\Delta}+{1 \over 2}\right)
\right]\,.\nonumber
\end{eqnarray}

\subsection{Spin two}
Similarly to the strategy in the spin one case, since a symmetric two-tensor $h_{\mu\nu}$ has 3 independent components in AdS$_2$ and the highest weight conditions are first order, it is sufficient to show that there are 3 independent solutions, each of which is in one-to-one correspondence with the scalar highest weight.

{\cal L}_{L_0} h_{\mu\nu} &=&{\cal L}_{[L_0,A_h]} g_{\mu\nu} =h{\cal L}_{A_h} g_{\mu\nu} =h h_{\mu\nu}\nonumber\\
{\cal L}_{L_+} h_{\mu\nu} &=&{\cal L}_{[L_+,A_h]} g_{\mu\nu}=0\nonumber\\
{\cal L}_{L_-^k} h_{\mu\nu} &=&{\cal L}_{[L_-^k,A_h]} g_{\mu\nu},
\end{eqnarray} 

where we have used ${\cal L}_{L_0} g_{\mu\nu}=0$ and the fact that ${\cal L}_{L_0} {\bf A}_h= h{\bf A}_h$. Similar results hold for $\tilde{A}_h$. This shows these highest weight spin-two modes are in one-to-one correspondence with the spin one highest weight (which in turn is in bijection with two copies of the scalar highest weight). Since there are two independent spin-one highest weight modes, we get two independent spin-two highest weight modes here, each with degeneracy $D_h$.

Similarly to the strategy in the spin one case, since a symmetric two-tensor $h_{\mu\nu}$ has 3 independent components in AdS$_2$ and the highest weight conditions are first order, it is sufficient to show that there are 3 independent solutions, each of which is in one-to-one correspondence with the scalar highest weight.

By Leibniz's rule and the fact that ${\cal L}_{L_0} g_{\mu\nu}={\cal L}_{L_+} g_{\mu\nu}={\cal L}_{L_-} g_{\mu\nu}=0$, we obtain
\begin{eqnarray}
{\cal L}_{L_0} h_{\mu\nu} &=& g_{\mu\nu} {\cal L}_{L_0} \phi_h = h h_{\mu\nu}, \nonumber\\
{\cal L}_{L_+} h_{\mu\nu} &=& g_{\mu\nu} {\cal L}_{L_+} \phi_h = 0, \nonumber\\
{\cal L}_{L_-^k} h_{\mu\nu} &=& g_{\mu\nu} {\cal L}_{L_-^k} \phi_h \,.
\end{eqnarray} Thus, this spin-two highest weight solution is in one-to-one correspondence with the scalar modes.

In short, we have exhibited three independent highest-weight spin-two modes, and they all come from scalar highest-weight modes. Thus, the zero modes of a massive spin two field on AdS$_2$ are the same as that of the scalar, but we have {\it three times} the degeneracy.

\section{Finite representations of $SO(d+1,1)$}
\label{sec:app1}
Let us study a Euclidean CFT$_d$ on $R^d$ with coordinates $x^\mu$ for $d=2n-1$.
The $d$-dimensional Euclidean conformal group is generated by the dilatation $D$, translations $P_\mu$, special conformal transformations $K_\mu$ and the $SO(d)$-rotation subalgebra $M_{\mu\nu}$.\footnote{For $d=1$, we have that $D=L_0$, $K=L_+$ and $P=L_-$.} They satisfy the algebra
\begin{eqnarray}\label{eq:confalgebra}
[D,P_\mu]&=& P_\mu,\quad [D,K_\mu]= -K_\mu,\quad
[K_\mu , P_\nu ] =2 \left( \delta_{\mu\nu} D - i M_{\mu\nu}\right) ,\nonumber\\
~[M_{\mu\nu}, P_\rho]& =& i (\delta_{\mu\rho} P_\nu - \delta_{\nu\rho} P_\mu),\quad
[M_{\mu\nu}, K_\rho] = i (\delta_{\mu\rho} K_\nu - \delta_{\nu\rho} K_\mu), \nonumber\\
~[M_{\mu\nu}, M_{\rho\sigma}] &= &i (\delta_{\mu\rho}M_{\nu\sigma}+\delta_{\nu\sigma} M_{\mu\rho} - \delta_{\mu\sigma} M_{\nu\rho}-\delta_{\nu\rho} M_{\mu\sigma}), 
\end{eqnarray} with the rest of the commutators being zero. In radial quantization,  the hermitian conjugate $\dag$ acts as

nexttext:
The pattern seems to be that for $h=-p$, the dimension is
\begin{eqnarray}
&&1+3+6+10+\ldots+(p+1)(p+2)/2+\ldots+10+6+3+1\nonumber\\
&=&\frac{(p+1)(p+2)}{2}+2\sum^p_{q=0} (q+1)(q+2)/2  =\frac{(p+1)(p+2)(2p+3)}{6} \nonumber\\
&=&\left.\frac{2p+d}{d} {p+d-1 \choose d-1} \right|_{d=3}\,.
\end{eqnarray}

mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E94.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Sigma_{\mu\nu}=-\frac{i}{4}\left[\gamma_{\mu},\gamma_{\nu}\right]" display="block"><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Σ</mi><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ν</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mi>i</mi><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><msub><mi>γ</mi><mi>μ</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>γ</mi><mi>ν</mi></msub><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
We follow the conventions in Chapter 3.1 of \cite{freedman2012supergravity} for Euclidean $\gamma_\mu$. The convention for $\Sigma_{\mu\nu}$ is such that it satisfies the same algebra as  $M_{\mu\nu}$ in Eq.~(\ref{eq:confalgebra}). 

In particular, for $d=3$ (or $n=1$), we have 2-component spinors and $2\times 2$ gamma matrices chosen as
\begin{eqnarray}
\gamma^1 &=& \sigma_1= \left( \begin{array}{ccc}
 0& 1 \\
 1 & 0 \end{array} \right)\nonumber\\
\gamma^2 &=& \sigma_2= \left( \begin{array}{ccc}
 0& -i \\
i & 0 \end{array} \right) \nonumber\\
\gamma^3 &=& \sigma_3=  \left( \begin{array}{ccc}
 1& 0 \\
 0 & -1 \end{array} \right) \,,
\end{eqnarray} where $\sigma_i$'s are the Pauli matrices.
The rest of the structures (e.g. how to build descendants and etc) are the same as in the scalar case, except we now have to keep track of the degeneracy in the $a$ index. In principle, we could perform the analysis for any $n$. However, due to the time-consuming nature of such analysis at higher dimensions and higher levels, here we shall only deal with the case of AdS$_4$ (i.e. $d=3$ or $n=1$).

\subsubsection{$d=3$}
At level zero, there are two states (since $2^n=2$).
At level one, since there are three $P_\mu$'s but there is a spinor degeneracy of $2$, there are $2\times 3 =6$  states. Similar counting gives degeneracy at a general level $k$. Up to level four, the eigenvalues of the inner-product matrix are:

prevtext:
We follow the conventions in Chapter 3.1 of \cite{freedman2012supergravity} for Euclidean $\gamma_\mu$. The convention for $\Sigma_{\mu\nu}$ is such that it satisfies the same algebra as  $M_{\mu\nu}$ in Eq.~(\ref{eq:confalgebra}). 

In particular, for $d=3$ (or $n=1$), we have 2-component spinors and $2\times 2$ gamma matrices chosen as
\begin{eqnarray}
\gamma^1 &=& \sigma_1= \left( \begin{array}{ccc}
 0& 1 \\
 1 & 0 \end{array} \right)\nonumber\\
\gamma^2 &=& \sigma_2= \left( \begin{array}{ccc}
 0& -i \\
i & 0 \end{array} \right) \nonumber\\
\gamma^3 &=& \sigma_3=  \left( \begin{array}{ccc}
 1& 0 \\
 0 & -1 \end{array} \right) \,,
\end{eqnarray} where $\sigma_i$'s are the Pauli matrices.
The rest of the structures (e.g. how to build descendants and etc) are the same as in the scalar case, except we now have to keep track of the degeneracy in the $a$ index. In principle, we could perform the analysis for any $n$. However, due to the time-consuming nature of such analysis at higher dimensions and higher levels, here we shall only deal with the case of AdS$_4$ (i.e. $d=3$ or $n=1$).

\subsubsection{$d=3$}
At level zero, there are two states (since $2^n=2$).
At level one, since there are three $P_\mu$'s but there is a spinor degeneracy of $2$, there are $2\times 3 =6$  states. Similar counting gives degeneracy at a general level $k$. Up to level four, the eigenvalues of the inner-product matrix are:
text:

\begin{array}{|c | l |c |}
\hline
k& \text{Eigenvalues} & \text{Multiplicity}\\
\hline
  0 & 1 & 2 \\
\hline
  1 & h-1 & 2 \\
\hline

\hline

\hline

\hline
  3 &  ( h +{1 \over 2}) h(h -1)&2 \\
\hline

\hline

\hline
   &  ( h+{1 \over 2}) ( h+\frac{3}{2}) ( h+\frac{5}{2}) ( h+\frac{7}{2}) &10\\
\hline
   &  ( h+{1 \over 2}) ( h+\frac{3}{2})  (h+\frac{5}{2})(h-1)  &14\\
\hline
\end{array}
\end{equation}
